channel.title: Ramah: Good News Feed
channel.description: Positive news stories from around the world, filtered by sentiment analysis

item.title: Stunning skies as Northern Lights seen in the UK
item.description: Skies across the UK were lit up in hues of green and pink by the Northern Lights on Monday evening.

item.title: UK approves Chinese ‘mega embassy’ in London after reassurances from spy chiefs
item.description: The UK communities secretary, Steve Reed, has given permission for China to build a vast new embassy near the Tower of London after spy chiefs told him that the risks to national security could be controlled and dealt with.

item.title: King Harold coins from 1066 and Roman artefacts top UK’s 2024 treasure finds
item.description: A hoard of pennies linked to Harold II and most likely buried on the eve of battle in 1066, a rare Roman vehicle fitting, and a group of early medieval objects are among the archaeological finds and treasure discovered in Britain in 2024.

item.title: The influencer racing to save Thailand’s most endangered sea mammal
item.description: Amateur conservationist and social media influencer Theerasak ‘Pop’ Saksritawee has a rare bond with Thailand’s critically endangered dugongs.

item.title: The influencer racing to save Thailand’s most endangered sea mammal
item.description: Amateur conservationist and social media influencer Theerasak 'Pop' Saksritawee has a rare bond with Thailand’s critically endangered dugongs.

item.title: Vine lays down marker as Watson wins blistering TDU prologue
item.description: Briton Sam Watson (Ineos Grenadiers) claimed victory in 4 minutes, 16.9 seconds.

item.title: India tightened its egg donation rules, creating a vibrant black market for sellers
item.description: India radically tightened its rules on egg donation to make it altruistic, but that move triggered a vibrant black market for human eggs.

item.title: Valentino, designer whose gowns made royals and movie stars feel beautiful, dies at 93
item.description: MILAN (AP) — Valentino Garavani, the jet-set Italian designer whose high-glamour gowns — often in his trademark shade of “Valentino red” — were fashion show staples for nearly half a century, died Monday.

item.title: Why have there been so many shark bites in Sydney? Experts say the conditions are a ‘perfect storm’
item.description: Four people have been attacked by sharks in New South Wales in 48 hours, including three incidents at Sydney beaches.

item.title: State's EPA recommends Valhalla gas project for approval
item.description: WA's Environmental Protection Authority has recommended a fracking proposal in the state's north go ahead.

item.title: Lookout made famous by K-pop star set to close after safety concerns
item.description: An iconic Blue Mountains viewpoint will be temporarily shut after a viral social media post results in "alarming" tourist numbers.

item.title: Climate change triggers 'remarkable response' from Antarctic penguins
item.description: A long-term study has found the breeding cycle of a penguin species in Antarctica is changing at the fastest rate recorded in birds, likely in response to climate change.

item.title: The pub that changed me: ‘It had some nefarious characters – but with lovely shoes’
item.description: In a packed pub, revellers chat, sip lager and look at their phones.

item.title: ‘I thought it was going to perish’: the remarkable revival of an endangered language in Lesotho
item.description: Tsotleho Mohale was addressing a group of people gathered on a mountainside still damp from an intense rainstorm that morning.

item.title: Australians must demand that their cultural custodians uphold freedom of speech | Margaret Simons
item.description: Is there a way forward for Australia’s cultural life after the cancellation of the 2026 Adelaide writers’ week and all the other controversies played out over the past year, in which the custodians of our culture seem to have crumbled under pressure, only to kinda, sorta and belatedly rally?.

item.title: Live: Maya Joint hunts maiden Aus Open win first up on day three
item.description: Local favourites Maya Joint and Taylah Preston are on court to start day three of the Australian Open, looking to win main draw matches at their home slam for the first time.

item.title: Kostoulas’s brilliant bicycle kick rescues point for Brighton against Bournemouth
item.description: Just when it seemed another match would be dominated by the dreariness of a debatable video assistant referee decision, a moment of majesty from Charalampos Kostoulas provided a pertinent reminder of the beauty that football can provide.

item.title: Karen Solie’s Wellwater wins TS Eliot poetry prize
item.description: The Canadian poet Karen Solie has won the 2025 TS Eliot poetry prize for a collection of work, Wellwater, which explores the destruction of the natural world.

item.title: Five quick hits: Stan the man wins as Tomljanović tells her dad to 'be quiet'
item.description: Day two of the tournament saw several Australians progress into the second round, however none in more strange fashion than Priscilla Hon.

item.title: How powerlifting made me feel good at sport
item.description: Movement was fun and instinctive.

item.title: Arizona a unanimous No. 1 for first time, Saint Louis and Miami of Ohio join AP Top 25
item.description: Arizona is the unanimous No.

item.title: Positive thinking could boost immune response to vaccines, say scientists
item.description: Positive thoughts may boost the immune system according to research that points to a connection between the mind and our body’s natural defences.

item.title: Nine easy swaps to reduce ultra-processed foods in your diet: it’s not an ‘all-or-nothing approach’
item.description: Australia, alongside the US and UK, has one of the world’s highest consumption rates of ultra-processed foods which have been linked to “multiple diet-related chronic diseases”, according to a global report of which Lawrence was a co-author.

item.title: In Davos, the rich talk about ‘global threats’. Here’s why they’re silent about the biggest of them all | Ingrid Robeyns
item.description: This week, hundreds of government leaders, heads of state, and business executives are gathering at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos.

item.title: Rukmini Iyer’s quick and easy recipe for harissa-spiked orzo with chickpeas and pine nuts | Quick and easy
item.description: This is my favourite store-cupboard dinner when faced with the pre-shop complaints that “there’s nothing in the fridge”.

item.title: Are we getting more savvy about our credit scores?
item.description: With lenders using credit scores to decide everything from phone contracts to car finance, experts say understanding how it works could make a meaningful difference.

item.title: NHS trust used charity funds for leaving party
item.description: An under-fire NHS trust has apologised after using money from charitable funds to throw a leaving party for its former chairman.

item.title: ‘I love that there’s this big gay thing in the middle of Scotland’: Ian McKellen and Graham Norton join Alan Cumming for Out in the Hills
item.description: Sir Ian McKellen is on stage blowing up a red balloon.

item.title: ‘Remarkable’ UPS driver ran into burning home to save woman, 101
item.description: A United Parcel Service driver at work recently charged into a burning home outside Los Angeles and carried a centenarian woman out to safety in what officials called a “remarkable” example of “people looking out for one another in a moment of need”.

item.title: Ecstasy and now a day off - Senegal fans around the world celebrate Afcon win
item.description: Senegal's President Bassirou Diomaye Faye has declared Monday a public holiday after the national team won the Africa Cup of Nations after beating tournament hosts Morocco 1-0 in a dramatic final on Sunday.

item.title: 'I felt so loved': Philippines star sends Aus Open crowds into a frenzy
item.description: It is rare a player ranked 49th in the world would attract a crowd that virtually brought a grand slam tournament to a standstill.

item.title: Japan’s prime minister calls snap election as approval ratings ride high
item.description: Japan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, has called a snap election as she attempts to capitalise on high approval ratings since becoming the country’s first female prime minister three months ago.

item.title: Wide sandy beaches and amazing seafood in western France
item.description: Dinner comes with a spectacle in La Tremblade.

item.title: A novelty golf-ball finder that conned the military: best podcasts of the week
item.description: This unbelievable, Alice Levine-narrated true story sees governments fooled by a fake bomb detector.

item.title: Alex de Minaur eases into Australian Open second round with routine win over lucky loser
item.description: His serve remains a work-in-progress, but a dominant Alex de Minaur sailed through the first round of the Australian Open with a professional dismantling of American Mackenzie McDonald.

item.title: ‘I’ve had to fight tooth and nail’: Amber Davies on Strictly trolls, Love Island hunks – and her Legally Blonde no-brainer
item.description: At the end of last year’s Strictly Come Dancing semi-final, pro dancer Nikita Kuzmin made a tearful appeal to camera, “I speak to the audience at home: guys, just please, please be kind!” His celebrity partner, Love Island winner, Dancing on Ice contestant and musical theatre actor Amber Davies, had been getting a lot of flak online.

item.title: Hunter posts inspiring Aus Open win after thinking her career was over
item.description: The month of April in 2024 was memorable for Storm Hunter in more ways than one.

item.title: Storm Hunter leads Australian Open local charge on day two with straight-sets win
item.description: Storm Hunter has put almost two years of injury pain behind her, becoming the second local woman to win her first-round match at the Australian Open.

item.title: The Papers: 'EU weighs up €93bn retaliation' and 'Raducanu's fine start'
item.description: Sign up for our morning newsletter and get BBC News in your inbox.

item.title: What it's like to play the world number one at the Australian Open
item.description: After reaching a career-high ranking of 74 three months ago, Adam Walton had reason to believe he could cause an upset or two at the Australian Open.

item.title: Socks, salsa and stand-up comedy... easy ways to find joy in January
item.description: There is a reason it is called Blue Monday.

item.title: Oxfam says super rich should be taxed to tackle inequality
item.description: Oxfam Australia is calling on the federal government to tax the super rich to help tackle growing inequality.

item.title: Two short but spectacular HS2 tunnels offer glimmer of hope for stalling project
item.description: Seventy metres down, in deep incognito beneath a disguised ventilation shaft in the Chilterns countryside, lies HS2’s buried treasure: two 10-mile tunnels, built to avoid an area of outstanding natural beauty, eerily spectacular in gleaming concrete.

item.title: ‘Brazen’ political influence of rich laid bare as wealth of billionaires reaches $18.3tn, says Oxfam
item.description: The world saw a record number of billionaires created last year, with a collective wealth of $18.3tn (£13.7tn), while global efforts stalled in the fight against poverty and hunger.

item.title: Live: Australia's perfect start brought to shuddering halt on day two
item.description: Australian wildcard Priscilla Hon gets her first main draw singles win at Melbourne Park since 2020 as Marina Stakusic succumbs to cramps, while men's sixth seed Alex de Minaur starts his grand slam campaign with a straightforward victory on Rod Laver Arena.

item.title: Lambert breaks through for maiden World Cup win on eve of Olympics
item.description: Adam Lambert has won his first snowboard cross World Cup event.

item.title: Fun and easy recipes kids can help with in the kitchen
item.description: Getting kids involved with cooking is not just a great way for them to learn about food, it may also make mealtimes less of a battle if they're eating something they've helped prepare (winning).

item.title: Live: China's economic growth on target, declining birth rate hits A2 Milk shares
item.description: Wall Street closed marginally lower ahead of the long weekend, but it was a threat from the White House to bring back punitive tariffs against European nations over Greenland that put the ASX on edge.

item.title: Smith amuses and delights, England all-rounder stars as Sixers lock in finals
item.description: The Sydney Sixers secured a BBL finals berth with a five-wicket win over the Brisbane Heat at the Gabba.

item.title: AI is an ethical, social and economic nightmare — and we're starting to wake up
item.description: As 2025 began, I thought humanity's biggest problem was climate change.

item.title: ‘It felt amazing to be on the start line again’: the rugby pro who became paralysed – and is aiming for the Paralympic Games
item.description: Aged 20, Taylor Gough had a car accident.

item.title: Expand credit unions to boost cheap credit to low-income people, Labour MPs urge Reeves
item.description: A group of Labour MPs have called on Rachel Reeves to support a huge expansion of credit unions to boost access to cheap credit for millions of people on low incomes.

item.title: Martin Luther King Jr. had a dream ... about health care
item.description: Growing up as a teenager in Kano State, Nigeria, in the 1980s, I loved to read.

item.title: How can we learn from unrequited love?

item.title: Australia’s koala paradox: why is the beloved marsupial endangered in parts but overabundant in others?
item.description: On French Island in Victoria’s Western Port Bay, koalas are dropping from trees.

item.title: The pitfalls of perfectionism – and why ‘good enough’ should be your goal | Gill Straker and Jacqui Winship
item.description: New year’s resolutions are catnip for perfectionism.

item.title: Venus Williams sets Australian Open record at age of 45 but falters with win in sight
item.description: Venus Williams set a record just by starting her first-round match at the Australian Open, a testament to her endurance and longevity at the highest level of tennis.

item.title: Minister 'confident' issues over Hillsborough Law can be resolved
item.description: Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy has said she is confident disagreements with campaigners over a new law designed to stop cover-ups can be resolved before it returns to Parliament on Monday.

item.title: Shane Lowry chips into water at 72nd hole to blow lead as Elvira wins in Dubai
item.description: Shane Lowry blew a one-shot lead on the last hole as Nacho Elvira recovered to claim victory in a dramatic finish to the Dubai Invitational.

item.title: ‘I looked exceptional but I was out of breath’: the bodybuilder who switched to mindful movement
item.description: That quest became an obsession: “How can I push myself to these extreme points, and then do it again and again and become better than last time?” He followed unsafe protocols shared by bodybuilding gurus to make his muscles pop, dangerously dehydrating his body ahead of competitions.

item.title: Sabalenka is a worthy lead in the theatre of tennis
item.description: Each time Aryna Sabalenka steps on court, the world number one creates the impression she is riding an emotional roller coaster.

item.title: This is how we do it: ‘Nobody’s enjoyed a night at the Premier Inn Milton Keynes more than us’
item.description: Beth and I met online 20 years ago, emailing back and forth for a good while before our first date – but once we met in person we only waited a few days to have sex.

item.title: The pub that changed me: ‘We celebrated Christmas in July – and suddenly every night was Saturday night’
item.description: I was an employee and a customer at this pub as a teenager in the early 1990s.

item.title: ‘Even thinking about Coldplay I get tearful’: Denise Lewis’s honest playlist

item.description: The older I get, the more profoundly I appreciate that, when I’m writing about sport, I’m also writing about love.

item.description: Katie McCabe had the last laugh in May.

item.title: Mum thanks strangers who rescued nine-month-old baby from burning car
item.description: A mother has thanked two strangers who rescued her nine-month-old baby from her burning car moments before it was engulfed in flames.

item.title: Great Britain edges Australia to win SailGP event in Perth
item.description: Reigning Sail Grand Prix champions Great Britain have made the best possible start to season 2026, taking the win in Fremantle with a strong two-day performance culminating with victory in Sunday's final.

item.description: The Guardian’s journalism is independent.

item.title: 'It's all about fun': Cosplayers unite in celebration of geek culture
item.description: The pop cultural Zeitgeist was captivated by the recent Stanger Things finale, a long-awaited conclusion wrapping up the popular TV show that initially centred on a group of nerdy kids playing Dungeons & Dragons.

item.title: World's first legally binding treaty to protect oceans takes effect
item.description: The first legally binding international treaty to protect the world's oceans has taken effect.

item.title: David Byrne review – hope, humanity and dancing in a superbly paced and choreographed show
item.description: Dressed from head to foot in iridescent orange, David Byrne and his 12-piece backing band look as if they’re about to burst into flames.

item.title: Australia dominate snowboard halfpipe as Scotty James wins final World Cup before Olympics
item.description: Snowboard king Scotty James has dazzled to reign supreme in the last World Cup halfpipe event before the Olympics, where he’ll be seeking an elusive gold medal.

item.title: I want to show the world what Africa is - YouTube star brings joy and tears on tour
item.description: One of the world's most popular content creators has been attracting huge crowds, mostly his young fans, as he undertakes a 20-nation tour of Africa, a continent he says is "full of surprises".

item.title: Live: Local wildcard nabs first win of Aus Open as thousands of fans stuck outside
item.description: Local wildcard Talia Gibson has become the first winner on day one of the Australian Open, while top seeds Carlos Alcaraz and Aryna Sabalenka are the main attractions tonight.

item.title: He loved his millennial style at 41. Then came the mockery
item.description: He diligently shares mirror selfies on Instagram, where everyone knows the more likes you get, the cooler you are.

item.title: European Union and Mercosur bloc of South American nations sign landmark free trade agreement
item.description: The European Union and the Mercosur bloc of South American countries formally signed a long-sought landmark free trade agreement on Saturday, capping more than a quarter-century of torturous negotiations to strengthen commercial ties in the face of rising protectionism and trade tensions around the world.

item.title: As ACA enrollment drops, hopes for Congress to restore funding are fading
item.description: ACA enrollment is down for the first time in 5 years, and people are facing enormous premium hikes.

item.title: There are fewer waves, but surfers love this coastal town
item.description: It's the picturesque kind of place travellers visit once and decide to stay.

item.title: Only a thrilling final can save a predictable Africa Cup of Nations from being forgotten | Jonathan Wilson
item.description: Sometimes a tournament’s greatest strength can be its greatest weakness.

item.title: 'Back to my best': Kerr's comeback continues with FA Cup double
item.description: Sam Kerr has continued her love affair with the Women's FA Cup, scoring twice for Chelsea to help ease the holders into the fifth round.

item.title: Urthboy AKA Tim Levinson: ‘My most chaotic gig? There’s a lot where it’s pretty good knowing we didn’t die’
item.description: The Herd’s heading back on the road to mark 20 years of The Sun Never Sets.

item.title: On the world's largest hospital ship volunteers give people a chance at a better life
item.description: On the largest civilian hospital ship in the world, Australian volunteer medical experts offer life-changing healthcare that is transforming lives.

item.title: Carrick has dream start as Mbeumo and Dorgu give Manchester United derby delight
item.description: On 64 minutes Michael Carrick’s second tenure went electric as Manchester United scored a classic breakaway goal by Bryan Mbeumo that sent the interim head coach berserk in the technical area.

item.title: Uganda’s President Yoweri Museveni wins seventh term with 71.65% of votes
item.description: KAMPALA, Uganda (AP) — Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni won his seventh term with 71.65% of votes, according to official results Saturday, defeating the youthful challenger who campaigned for change after four decades of the same government.

item.title: Ugandan leader to extend 40-year rule after being declared winner of contested poll
item.description: President Yoweri Museveni has been declared the winner of Thursday's election extending his four decades in power by another five years.

item.title: Ukrainian delegation arrives in US for peace talks as Russia hammers energy sites
item.description: KYIV, Ukraine (AP) — A Ukrainian delegation arrived in the United States for talks Saturday on a U.S.-led diplomatic push to end the nearly 4-year-old war as Russian attacks again took aim at Ukraine’s power grid, cutting electricity and heating in freezing temperatures.

item.title: Confidence runs high in London’s Little Morocco as Afcon glory beckons
item.description: London’s Little Morocco is brimming with pride and anticipation.

item.title: Opinion: Remembering Ai, a remarkably intelligent chimpanzee
item.description: Ai, a chimpanzee who was born in West Africa and came to the Primate Research Institute of Kyoto University in Japan when she was a year old, has died of natural causes at the age of 49.

item.title: The CFPB experienced an exceptionally turbulent year. Here's why
item.description: It's been a challenging year for the consumer watchdog agency, as the Trump administration has tried to deny it funding and lay off most of its staff.

item.title: Why Djokovic won't be burdened by grand slam record chase
item.description: Novak Djokovic won't let his pursuit of a record 25th grand slam title prove a burden in Melbourne as he tries to break Carlos Alcaraz and Jannik Sinner's recent stranglehold over the tennis majors.

item.description: SailGP debutant Sweden is locked in a three-way tie for the lead after the first day of racing in Fremantle, with the Australian boat Flying Roos well placed in fourth spot heading into Sunday's races.

item.title: Love of US folk parade sees gran, 93, fly for first time in 30 years
item.description: Avril Davidge, 93, had never been to America, hadn't been on a plane in 30 years and rarely left her flat.

item.description: Avril Davidge is 93 and had never been to America in her life, but after going down a YouTube rabbit hole and falling in love with a folk parade in Philadelphia, she boarded a plane for the first time in 30 years to see it for herself.

item.title: Are our bodies full of microplastics or not? There’s a way to resolve this debate, and scientists must hurry | Debora MacKenzie
item.description: Are we being injured and killed by ubiquitous, teeny-tiny shards of toxic plastic? Or aren’t we? For many months, the Guardian has reported a series of worrying scientific results that our bodies are full of jagged microplastic particles that could be giving us everything from heart attacks to reproductive problems.

item.title: Australia news live: Christian and Muslim faith leaders express ‘deep concerns’ about Labor bill’s impact on free speech

item.title: How young people are finding ways to connect for free
item.description: The ubiquity of social media means, in some ways, we are more connected than ever.

item.title: What we know about the Great Ocean Road's unprecedented weather event

item.title: San Francisco to make childcare free for families earning up to $230,000
item.description: San Francisco will offer free childcare to families earning less than $230,000 a year, and a 50% subsidy to those earning up to $310,000, in an expansion of the city’s childcare offerings designed to make one of the world’s most expensive cities more affordable for residents.
